text: William was the most pleasurable baby
he made being first-time mum the best
job in the world he was just happy he
was content he was just full of smiles
when he smiled it just made you smile
when he became Paulie during October he
developed a cough and after after a few
days he took him to the doctors the
cough persisted and it got a little bit
worse it became more frequent so we took
him back to the doctors again and again
they told us it was just a cough nothing
to worry about
and then we have started vomiting and
after he was eating and so we took him
back again and we saw a different doctor
but he just started deteriorating and he
started going off going off his food and
he was just not as playful and a little
bit more tired we were just told it it's
nothing grisly so not to worry go home
and that's what we did and we went home
he started vomiting so he called 1 1 1
and we explained the situation and the
call handler went through the questions
and the triage and we answered the
questions and they said oh it is nothing
serious
well we were reassured that we were
doing the right thing regardless of you
know that the previous appointment and
the call with one on one and so that was
that they rubbed his cheek and it was
warm we didn't move and so I put my
office through the bar so that cop and
his arm was cool I brought up the curb
that he was gone after the inquest it
became evident that there were failings
in in Williams care in different
different agencies we didn't know what
sepsis was we weren't alerted to what
the symptoms all the signs of sepsis
should be I was frantically checking
William all the time for a rash because
it's drummed into your head to check for
a rash I didn't think I didn't think
sepsis because I didn't know what sepsis
was
I think if if GPS can't recognize it or
aren't recognizing it how a parent's
supposed to look out for it the UK
second biggest killer and hardly anyone

that research we have to get that
information out there
